@ILSecOfState So, thanks @ILSecOfState. Feeling really welcome. Almost feels like the DMV is a revenue oriented mechanism, rather than a city service.
@ILSecOfState Two for "Improper Placement of Sticker"- fines easier avoided with a warning, or if anyone mentioned sticker placement during my 3hrs at DMV
I've had a Chicago City Sticker for one week and I have three parking tickets. One obviously erroneous at a meter I paid for. @ILSecOfState
@laurenancona Second City for comedy, Kingston Mines for jazz, Half Acre for beer, but hey, I just got here. Pretty cool city though.

RT @UChicagoCAPP: Fascinating: @Geneorama presenting on @ChicagoCDO Office's West Nike Virus prediction work. Mixed effects GLM worked best…
@chihacknight That was in sample accuracy! The 65% was out of sample predictive accuracy. Very tough problem though, so understandable percentage.
@sdbieler @hannah_recht This was super useful, and you were exactly as prepared for this question as @hannah_recht said you would be. Many thanks! Hope NYU is great
@sdbieler @hannah_recht Right ok - so there's a ton of variance between jurisdictions, makes sense. Anything specific to one important dataset?
@sdbieler Something that might have disastrous consequences for an analyst who didn't know it would be great. BTW @hannah_recht nominated you for this
@sdbieler Like, something specific to justice policy research/data, but you'd know it if you were an expert in the field and worked with that data
@sdbieler I'm looking for an example of a fact that you would NEED to know to properly examine a (any) justice policy dataset.
@sdbieler Damnit Sam - I have a question for you but apparently you don't follow me so I've gotta do this nonsense w/o direct messenger...

It just seems like so much has changed, you'd think there'd be room for improvement?

I started listening to @TlkngMchns for like 5 seconds & I can't believe I lapsed.

Best line so far, @lawrennd: "The truth is intractable"
Ok daily driving commute to work. Let's do this. Very open to suggestions as to what I'm missing. https://t.co/GFw3uOUVLi
RT @neiltyson: In school, we rarely learn probability & statistics, leaving us victims of our mind’s own inability to process random events.

@DrClimate @ResBaz @dfflanders @nikkirubinstein Also there's a tremendous amount of health data analysis in R and SAS. That part is very surprising, but could be related to this sample.

Very likely an important factor. https://t.co/2mXMsYVjq2
@PaulBlu @SlaughterAM @NewAmerica @Google @WashPostDC One read into @SlaughterAM's response, and I don't think it really addressed the questions that I have: https://t.co/RcXz8lydZb
@awunderground Literally hiding part of the graph by default. Most haven't been problematic, afew have, but not novel enough to be exciting given that flaw
@awunderground I mean, small multiple density charts are fine. There's just no clear reason for them to overlap by default, especially w/o transparency
@awunderground There's no specific name for that, which is fine. It doesn't need one and frankly neither did #joyplots, whose bandwagon I'm not on so much.
@awunderground One data point gets one circle here. So it's really just overlapping small multiples of scaled half-circle plots.
@awunderground I think not, despite looking similar. Joy plots are overlapping small multiples of smoothed histograms. No binning/kernel density here
RT @cblatts: In college, I believed this deeply. It's fundamental to justify libertarian stance. Learning it was empirically false changed…
RT @TheRealDerv: lol if you think i actually hired a photographer to take pictures of my new puppy then you're exactly right bc i totally d…
@CookieSci @drob @nytgraphics Sure, but harder to mentally aggregate (sum to their total) across bars than with scaled circles, treemaps, or similar graphs.
@drob @nytgraphics In the NYT example there is added info in the ability to look at groups (compare all red to all green) you would not get in bar plot.
@drob Stronger example of this graph done well comes from @nytgraphics where the ordering and color adds value https://t.co/xJC4UGcnTF https://t.co/HBqS0Lfysm
@drob Hm. Well scaled circles have notably better properties than word clouds. Words as visual encoding are imprecise & easy to misinterpret size

@Elijah_Meeks Ah ok. Those extensions are maybe more analogous to d3's layouts? I'd still put ggplot fairly high on the expressiveness scale.
@Elijah_Meeks You're referring to qplot and ggplot as the two methods?
@Elijah_Meeks I tend to think on a scale of expressiveness, in which d3 is at the very top, and chart makers (Excel/tableau) are the very bottom.
Note from an old colleague upon hearing I moved to Chicago "A fun fact you may need this winter: Fahrenheit and Celsius scales meet at -40°"
